content.rendered:
The literature reveals a lengthy list of DDI prediction models and drug interaction checkers; they both target only the interactions corresponding to one drug at a time, therefore not considering the poly-medication situations. Due to the complexity problems entailed by multiple (and some unexpected) interactions emerging in therapies that require a simultaneous administration of multiple drugs, in silico models have been proposed in accordance with official documents [1] and other important scientific papers [2][3]. Such recent developments were spurred by the tremendous developments in the field of network science [4][5], including its medical [6][7] and biological [8][9] applications. The network applications to the fields of biochemistry and pharmacology led to modeling the so-called interaction networks or interactomes [7]. A DDI interactome is a complex network where the nodes represent drugs and the links between them correspond to drug interactions. 

Taking DDI interactomes as inputs, the algorithms for complex network processing are used to reveal the following aspects: 

  1. Predicting potentially strong interactions that were previously unknown [10][11][12][13][14]; this idea is behind the development of software tools for drug interaction alert systems [15][16]; 
  2. Avoiding certain interactions during the drug design process, by employing computer-aided design tools [2][17]. 

Consequently, for our HYPERION project, the specific objectives are: 

O1 – Build, at server level, the drug interaction networks with data collected from public drug databases; 

O2 – Build, at server level, the relevant DDI selection (i.e., filtering) model, using a machine learning approach that predicts the interaction strength; 

O3 – Develop, at an individual user level, a smartphone application that will issue personalized drug interaction alerts (i.e., drug-drug and drug-food interactions); these alerts will be filtered according to their strength and relevance.
